abstract: <jats:p>This paper provides new taxonomic and biological data on a complex of gracillariid moths in the endemic genus <jats:italic>Philodoria</jats:italic> Walsingham, 1907 that are associated with <jats:italic>Myrsine</jats:italic> (Primulaceae) in the Hawaiian Islands, United States. Two new species, <jats:italic>Philodoriakauaulaensis</jats:italic> Kobayashi, Johns &amp; Kawahara, <jats:bold>sp. n.</jats:bold> (host: <jats:italic>Myrsinelanaiensis</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>M.lessertiana</jats:italic>, and <jats:italic>M.sandwicensis</jats:italic>) and <jats:italic>P.kolea</jats:italic> Kobayashi, Johns &amp; Kawahara, <jats:bold>sp. n.</jats:bold> (host: <jats:italic>M.lessertiana</jats:italic>) are described. Biological data are provided for two previously described species that also feed on <jats:italic>Myrsine</jats:italic>: <jats:italic>P.auromagnifica</jats:italic> Walsingham, 1907 and <jats:italic>P.succedanea</jats:italic> Walsingham, 1907. For the first time we detail and illustrate genital structures, immature stages, biology, and host plants of <jats:italic>P.auromagnifica</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>P.succedanea</jats:italic>. <jats:italic>Philodoriakolea</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>P.auromagnifica</jats:italic>, and <jats:italic>P.succedanea</jats:italic> occur in sympatry on the island of Hawaii (Big Island), but each species differs in behavioral characters: <jats:italic>P.kolea</jats:italic> utilizes leaves of seedlings and forms a serpentine mine, whereas the latter two utilize leaves of larger plants, and form linear or serpentine to blotch mines. More broadly, leaf mine forms and diagnostic characteristics of the <jats:italic>Myrsine</jats:italic>-feeding species complex of <jats:italic>Philodoria</jats:italic> (as currently known) are reviewed and illustrated.</jats:p>
title: Hawaiian Philodoria (Lepidoptera, Gracillariidae, Ornixolinae) leaf mining moths on Myrsine (Primulaceae): two new species and biological data
